direction.raw_text: Jenny liked me for some reason.  I felt like I owed her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who'd Jenny get it off of -- this grass or whatever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (self-conscious again) Not me, man.  I'm no drug dealer, what you think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re Ed's tattoos) I think you didn't get that lot in the Navy, doing your National Service.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already told you, man.  Corcoran.  Know what that is?  State prison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick's a nick, n' it?  No matter what state you're in.  State of remorse, most likely -- for gettin' caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's not me anymore.  That's when I was into the gang lifestyle.  That's not who I am now.  Five years in the joint -- that's it for me, man. Now Wilson drops the clanger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just got out meself, didn't I. And Ed turns.  Looks at Wilson.  Fellow ex-con.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. WILSON'S MOTEL.  NIGHT. Wilson out of the car, shuts the passenger door.  Ed on the other side, looks over the roof at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go home, man. (plane taking off in background) Get on a plane. Wilson has other plans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be needing a shooter. Makes his fingers like a gun.  And a clicking sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (comes quickly over) You're kiddin' me, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I do, then, look in the bleedin' Yellow Pages?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (an urgent whisper) These are not guys you can just go run a number on, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking around) Thought perhaps there'd be dispensing machines, you know.  Bung in your coins, come out with a .44 Magnum, fully-loaded. Ed throws up his hands, walks back to his driver's side door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you a resident of California? You gonna fill out forms, man?  Do the background check?  Go through a three-day waiting period?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sod that.  Gotta get back before my probation officer wonders where I've skived off to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probation?  Man, you crazy.  They shouldn't've let you outta your country, much less prison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travelling on a dodgy passport, n' all. Walks round to come face to face with Ed once more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is why I thought, save some time, get what I need under the table, like. ED As if resigned and mulling the problem over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under the table?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. GUN SHOW.  DAY. Hundreds of tables.  Under bright lights.  Displaying every kind of firearm.  Handguns, rifles, shotguns, parts to make machine guns.  A weapons bazaar. WILSON AND ED Walking around.  Even a cool customer like Wilson can't help but be impressed by America's loving embrace of senseless mayhem. DEALERS Touting their wares. VISITORS Trying out pistol grips -- or pushing baby carriages.  Guys in fatigue jackets with toddlers on their shoulders.  Women in stretch pants looking for a little something in personal protection. WILSON Doesn't know where to look.  At the booth featuring "Classic Cowboy Collectibles" -- or the most OBESE COUPLE he's ever seen who just walked by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attention:  the long-range vermin- shooting panel is due to commence in two minutes in the blue room at the rear of the Convention Center. ... and other anomalous oddball ANNOUNCEMENTS in the background as long as we're here. DEMONSTRATION At a booth selling laser attachments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BeamSight II is easily mountable on any shotgun, rifle, or sidearm and will project a small, bright red dot directly onto the point where your weapon is aimed ... For purposes of display, a smiling YOUNG WOMAN is the "target." WILSON Walking past, almost subliminally noting the Young Woman with the symbol of death on her. TABLE A .45 passed from a DEALER's hand to Wilson's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man knows what he likes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (he'll talk if Wilson won't) Lookin' good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (while Wilson checks) That's a high-end item.  Total reliability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you call that -- the Protector?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.  Won't find a better CQC on the market. Wilson's eyes glance up -- but Ed asks the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close Quarters Combat.  Keep one in my own home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trouble is, I'm not at home, see. Fancied a bit of target shooting, y'know, while I'm here -- with me mate. Nods at Ed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh really?  Where you from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: England. (sighting the weapon) Only, we saw there was a show on, thought I might pick something up for a price, type of thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came to the right place, sir.  My wife's second cousin is English.  Well, Scotch-Irish.  Can I interest you in a holster?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just luck, this, really.  Never been to one of these before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're in gun country now, my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (picks up another, checks it out) Been to the Boat Show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (re Wilson's new selection) Packs a punch, but it's compact, has accessible features -- makes a nice concealed-carry piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (playing the reluctant buyer) He don't have a concealed weapons permit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't have time for a lot of paperwork, y'know.  Just popped over on a quick visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can take care of the paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No problem.  If you don't have a problem with me reporting this gun stolen. A look of understanding between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  Not at all. (to Ed) Do we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, it's already a steal, n'it -- what you said -- four hundred for this one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll have to add another two hundred on top of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, aye?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (another look) ... for the paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. ED'S CAR.  DAY. Ed drives.  Nervous at Wilson handling his new gun purchase beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Violation of my parole, this. (a perfect pause)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goin' abroad. Ed shakes his head at Wilson's sense of humor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hadda show up on a weekend.  This weekend.  Wouldn't've even been a gun show ... for another month.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucking out of order, that.  Shouldn't be allowed. As he puts away a box of ammo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now what.  You gonna take your new arsenal, go visit Terry Valentine, just like that?  Boom bam boom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's only insurance.  Can't be too careful.  This Terry Valentine, he's probably a wonderful fella.  They were together how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five years, I think.  Long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, there you are.  Jen must've liked him. Doesn't make Ed feel any better.  Nor does the way Wilson seems now to be studying Ed's driving techniques.  Paying attention to the way traffic lights and left-turn lanes and cars without clutches work over here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (remembering) Jenny told me she met him at the beach. Got blinded by his smile. (beat) You believe that shit?  Son of a bitch never smiled at me.  Buried her at a "private" service.  Private for who. Him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (confused) Hang about.  I thought you said he come into the restaurant where you worked with Jenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He came in with Jenny to the restaurant where I work.  That's not where they met.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's where you met Jenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no -- Jenny used to work as a waitress.  Before she met him.  But that's not where she met me.  Not in my restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd the two of you hook up, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jenny was in my acting class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. RENTAL CAR.  DAY. Wilson at the wheel himself.  Getting the hang of L.A. Driving downtown.  Along one of the major boulevards. Glances at a street sign as he goes by.  Picks up the map book on the seat beside him to check his route. EXT. BOULEVARD.  DAY. Wilson makes a sudden lane change to avoid getting fed in the wrong direction.  Gets HONKED by another driver. EXT. A STREET DOWNTOWN.  DAY. Wilson cruises past a particular building.  We don't have to really clearly see it just yet (we saw it in the flash cuts) -- more important we see him seeing it.  Casing it with the eyes of a professional.  Sniffing it out; the instinct of a predator after prey. INT. CAR.  DAY. Parks it.  Produces the little leather travel kit we saw him unpack at his motel.  Unzips it.  Under the usual assortment of clippers, razors, etc., is a hidden layer -- storing still more personalized items:  a set of select slim lockpicking/cutting tools. EXT. SIDE STREET.  DAY. Wilson locks the car.  Walks away.  STAY with him. AROUND THE CORNER He walks down the block.  A nice long walk.  What we get out of it besides a sense of Wilson -- cool cat; ambling along; loner; sun beating down; not bothered; his shadow doubling him -- is this: The building approaching.  The one he has his eye on.  The target.  It's across the street.  A kind of flat windowless warehouse with adjoining loading yard.  Loading yard surrounded by a chain-link fence -- topped with barbed wire. The actual geography of where he left his car in relation to this building.  Safely around the corner.  And how he might practically get back to it, either this same way or via a more circuitous route round another block. The sense you get in downtown L.A. on a lazy Saturday afternoon that you're in a ghost town.  Particularly in this shabby kind of industrial section. EXT. THE BUILDING. Wilson crosses over to it now.  From sunny to shade. Walks past the chain-link fence.  The padlocked gate, big enough to accommodate the (couple of) trucks parked within the compound. Walks past the closed security door which would appear to be the building's main entrance. Round the next corner -- SEES there's a steel back door as well. Comes around this block again.  Looking surreptitiously around now.  Streets here utterly deserted.  Not even a passing car. Crappy residential building on an opposite corner, SPANISH MUSIC blaring from one of the open windows, but not with a direct view on the loading yard fence on this side.  Wilson nearing it now -- taking something out of his pocket.  One of the mysterious metallic tools from his travel kit.  Snaps his wrist, unfolding the tool with a CRACK.  Wire cutters. He doesn't go for the gate, the padlock, like we might have thought.  He suddenly drops to one knee, in shadow where the fence meets the adjoining building.  SNAP, SNAP, SNAP, SNAP, SNAP -- so quick, with great dexterity, though his face grimaces with the strength he has to exert with each application of pressure -- he cuts just as many links as he knows he needs to push in a little flap of fence and roll under.  Whole thing accomplished in seconds. LOADING YARD Walks fast to the cover of the trucks.  Passes.  Looks around.  Cement loading docks and bays.  Shuttered doors.  He jumps up to one, puts his ear to the metal.  Listens awhile. WILSON Scans the wall for any sign of an alarm box or anything. Then cocks an ear upwards... CAMERA CRANING UP to show us what he hears:  an air-conditioning unit HUMMING away.  Which means someone must be inside. Wilson looks back at his entry options.  Not the loading doors -- but a conventional door at one end, with a conventional lock his eye zeroes in on.  Gets out his tools, going over. INT. WAREHOUSE HALLWAY. A SCRATCHING at the door.  It opens.  He's in. Waits.  Cautious.  Nothing.  He starts along the hallway. INT. WAREHOUSE. A SUPERVISOR (the one from the flash cuts) does a double take as Wilson passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! Wilson stops and turns.  Says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you get in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You walked. (coming over) What the hell are you doing here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking for a bloke named Valentine. Know him? MEAT PUPPETS (who we saw before as well) who work here gathering.  The Supervisor and the Meat Puppets exchange glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's expecting you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat) I doubt it. The Supervisor moves toward Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So why would he want to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a message for him.  About Jennifer Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jennifer Wilson. More looks are exchanged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I know her, all right.  She came down here once, stirred up a shitstorm. We lost a full day's work, took me weeks to get back on schedule.  If she hadn't a' been Terry's woman I would've broke her jaw.  'Course, she's nobody's problem now. Wilson stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Valentine here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think? Wilson looks at the Meat Puppets, the loading area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, get the fuck out of here before you get hurt.  Who the fuck do you think you are, waltzing in here, asking questions? Wilson just looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you hear me, asshole? The Supervisor shoves him.  The Meat Puppets move a little in anticipation.  Wilson isn't giving any indication that he's going to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, you really want your ass kicked, don't you? He pushes Wilson again, hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, get outta here. He pushes Wilson again.  Still, Wilson won't leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuckin' nut.  Go on. This time he tries to slap Wilson.  Wilson blocks the Supervisor's hand and then punches him, hard.  The Supervisor stumbles back and falls to the floor. THE MEAT PUPPETS Move to Wilson.  He tries to fend them off, but there are too many.  They beat him.  When they find that he's armed, they beat him harder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BUILDING.  DAY. Wilson is taken outside and dumped.  After a moment, he gets to his feet.  Dusting himself.  Reaches for ANOTHER GUN tucked in his lower back.  He re-enters the building. A beat.  We hear several SHOTS. Seconds later, one of the Meat Puppets comes stumbling out of the door, terrified.  He runs past us, fast. A moment later, Wilson emerges, gun in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell him.  You tell him I'm coming!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT./EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DUSK. A series of images that prove Valentine (whoever he is) has taste, wealth, and influence, stretching back a good three decades at least. Walking through some of these shots is a young beauty in a bathing suit named ADHARA.  She advances slowly, not entirely sure of herself, and stops to look at things just like we do. At one point she looks to see a BEEFY GUY (GORDON) sitting at the kitchen counter, flipping through a magazine.  He looks her up and down, more from reflex than anything. She continues on.  Eventually she emerges through sliding glass doors and on to a patio. HER POV A figure by the pool, talking on the phone.  His back to us. The pool is spectacular, mosaic tile bottomed. ADHARA Approaches, then sits beside him.  His voice is soothing, but with the tiniest hint of exasperation that comes with being slightly ahead of everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Not before.  Not before .  Think about it. What does it mean?  What -- no, I'm not. Think.  Yes.  See?  You figured it out all by yourself.  I know.  Are we done? Okay. He hangs up, stands, still doesn't turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adhara.  I told your father, if you're looking for a name, you can't go wrong with a constellation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to hate it.  Now I like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could be worse, he could've named you Reticulum. He turns and we see him for the first time. VALENTINE Polished.  Handsome.  Charismatic.  Especially when he's smiling like he is now.  He leans over and kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anything in the world that you want or need?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to know why you need that scary guy in your house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon?  He's been with me for years. He's not as tough as he looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what good is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it possible that you're too young to be acquainted with the idea of loyalty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that a problem?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for you, clearly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm loyal to things that make me happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I a thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're certainly not a person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  You're not specific enough to be a person.  You're more like a vibe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad we're having this chat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a knock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a compliment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an observation.  Like:  I'm hungry. When are we eating?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As soon as you get dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything but Japanese.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not into finger foods.  Too fussy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like do-it-yourself cuisine. Buffets.  Salad bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You demand to be served.  A fork fetishist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just fuel to me.  I'm not there for distractions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For some, eating is a sensual experience. The sensual experience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Gordon's always saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, god. His cell phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Yes. He listens, then looks up at his balcony, where a MAN (AVERY) stands holding a phone, obviously talking to Valentine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) I'll be there as soon as I can. He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can leave as soon as you're ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. EXT. BALCONY.  EVENING. Valentine approaches Avery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's been some trouble downtown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the papers used to call a "gangland slaying."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our black friends?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Terry.  They don't work like that. Jenny Wilson's father paid a little visit, left a message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought he was in prison, in England.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, either they have a very liberal work-release program, or he's out, because he's here in L.A., looking for you. Valentine is a little ruffled.  Maybe Avery likes that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do we do? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We wait, and we watch. Valentine just looks at him. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  POOLSIDE.  EVENING. Adhara approaches Valentine, who stands staring at the pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Italian?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Italian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not who, food.  Should we get Italian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Turns to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Are you ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as I don't have to pass Gordon again.  I'm never ready for that. He smiles, rises, and offers her his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I know another way out. She takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING.  EVENING. ELAINE on her way in.  Handsome woman.  Intelligent, capable- looking.  Passes Wilson who's leaning somewhere smoking. ELAINE Aware as a wary woman will be of a strange man's presence without necessarily having looked at him.  Well aware too that he stayed where he was -- so she unworriedly unlocks the building's security gate and goes through to the inner -- COURTYARD -- and closes the gate behind her, now seeing him amble up, arriving as it CLICKS shut between them.  He's looking at her a certain way.  She looks back.  And knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're Jenny's father. And the recognition on his part:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Had a feeling it was you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look alike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cigarette in hand) Perhaps it was the smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not her brand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She used to pinch 'em off me. (trying to defuse Elaine's cold stare) Funny that.  One thing she never tried to get me to stop. Elaine doesn't soften.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you come here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanted to talk to you, didn't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, why did you come here? America.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sort a few things out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Been busy, have you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How d'you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was skint -- didn't have no money to get here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not what I heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you were -- what's that adorable phrase? -- "at Her Majesty's pleasure."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was the bars, then. Indicating his face, viewed by Elaine through the barred security gate that divides them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In any case, I don't suppose the salary you make sewing mailbags is really commensurate with international airline travel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sewing mailbags?  Me?  Never did an honest day's work in my life, dear. Wasn't about to start when I was in stir -- not with all that leisure time on my hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And not with all that buried loot you had waiting for you when you got out.  From the Wembley Staduim job, wasn't it?  Pink Floyd concert receipts.  Jenny would've been ... fourteen at the time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to conceal his surprise) Hardly buried.  Earning interest, love. Earning interest in an offshore account. Tidy little premium per annum, that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that kind of security can't be bought.  Must be more comforting than a daughter to greet you. She turns to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, aren't you gonna let me in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (without looking back) Try calling me again. INT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT.  EVENING. She comes in.  A modest studio apartment.  Puts her bag on the kitchenette countertop.  Glances at her answer machine to see if she has any messages.  The phone RINGS.  She sits down glumly on her couch, holds her head in her hands. EXT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT BUILDING.  EVENING. Wilson gives up, starts to walk away.  The gate BUZZES. INT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT.  EVENING. Elaine opens the door.  Wilson in the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just going to toss some vegetable rolls in the microwave, open a can of diet soda. (beat) Want to take me out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. RESTAURANT.  NIGHT. Wilson and Elaine at a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... No, I went in for more improving pastimes.  Philosophy classes, language courses, European history, all that lark. Did you know that in Paris in the Eighteenth Century there were more rats in people's houses than there were people in people's houses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like Beverly Hills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, are you always this sarky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarcastic, moi?  Maybe I'll mellow when my ship comes in.  It's expected any day now.  I'm all packed and ready to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weren't you on a television series?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (has he seen it?) If it played in England somebody owes me money.  Who told you that -- Eddie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yes) Said it went on for donkey's years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three seasons.  They found that's the limit of human tolerance when it comes to following the adventures of a family of Mormons on the Chisum Trail. (blinks coquettishly) I was wife number three -- the ingenue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it just ended, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now who's being sarcastic?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you've lost as many years as I have, love, puts things in perspective, know what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I guess the rest of us have no excuse for wondering where the time went. (raises her drink) It must've been the bars. Their food arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a kind of prison, doing a series. Early to bed, early to rise, no time off for good behavior, you grab the boodle for as long as it lasts. (the kicker) Only difference is you can't get arrested afterwards. Wilson appears fascinated by the cold glasses of water on the table.  Ice cubes CLINKING as he holds his.  A BUSBOY bringing them to other people, too, just like that, without anyone even asking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe Jenny told you all that. About me.  She was always so embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (correcting) Ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not ashamed. Wilson looks at her.  Okay.  What then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She never told Eddie, though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She never told anyone else. (making light now) About the convict strain -- or is it stain?  No, I was privileged.  I was someone who helped Jenny efface her past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you manage that, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I'm not honing my craft in episodic television I do double-duty as a voice coach.  Not that her accent would have hobbled her progress.  Not with that look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, she started all that in London.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Modelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Learnin' 'ow to speak proper. (putting it on a bit there. Then, upper crust:) Central School of Speech and Drama. It's no doddle gettin' in there, y'know. At seventeen.  They offered her a place at RADA n' all, only she'd've had to wait till the next session and she was always in hurry to get on, was Jenny.  She could talk posh without any training, when she was knee-high to a grasshopper. (indicating himself) Show up the old man, you know. Elaine smiles slightly.  None of this information new to her. But warming to this man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You weren't disappointed in her, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In Jenny?  'Course not.  How could I be. 'Course I wasn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was twenty-one when she came to me. (looks at him) ... Straight from leaving you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Footloose and fancy free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was happy here.  However the two of you might have parted.  Don't think she wasn't. It's because Wilson thinks the opposite that he's here. Looks at Elaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the trouble, n' it. (hard as nails again) She enjoyed life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. OCEANFRONT.  NIGHT. They walk along the seafront.  We HEAR the ocean but can't see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you get in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yesterday.  Afternoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (occurs to her) You haven't been lurking outside my building all day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I had -- some other matters to attend to, you know.  Getting a car sorted ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might've been away for the weekend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I reckoned, Saturday night, if you were goin' out, you'd probably have to come home first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you've seen Eddie Rama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, saw Eddie, yeah.  Me and him are muckers. Mates.  Friends.  Makes a kind of bonding gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should really give him a call.  He's a character, isn't he.  Well, not to you. I meant to us squares in the outside world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He give me your address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave him yours.  Said, here, you want to write, I think this is a relative.  I guess I thought I was being true to Jenny.  Who told me she didn't have a father -- before proceeding of course to tell me why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, don't suppose she did, really, most of her life.  On her own after her mum died.  Aunts and uncles for a time -- and then the bright lights beckoned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you still married at the time -- to Jenny's mother, I mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nah, we split up when Jenny was six.  Her second husband done a runner after she got sick.  They give me compassionate leave from Parkhurst to go visit her in hospital.  We were always mates, me and Jenny's mum.  I like to think they're together again now.  Y'know.  Heavenly choir. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The address Jenny gave me, that wasn't a prison, was it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nah, accommodation address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that, like a P.O. box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something like that, yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you get your bank statements. Wilson gives a laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you gotta have something permanent, don'tcha.  Even if it's a hole in the wall.  No matter which jug I might be transferred to, I always got someone on the out checks up on it for me, see. Anything I need to know, comes round on visitor's day -- word in my ear. Elaine pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some word. Wilson leans on the wall overlooking the black ocean.  Sound of WAVES gently lapping the beach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already knew.  Knew beforehand.  When was it supposed to have happened? -- two o'clock in the morning, Eddie said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (watching him) That's what was estimated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight hours difference between here and London.  Would've been, what, ten in the morning, my time.  I was just coming out on the yard.  Now, I was in the habit of saving my newspaper till then.  Bit of fresh air, stretch me legs -- well, stretch the day out, really, that's what you wanna do.  And I'll tell ya:  I couldn't open the paper.  Could not pry the pages apart -- it was like they was glued together.  That's how weak my hands went.  Thought I was having heart attack, only I knew I wasn't.  Bloke come up to me, he says, Dave, he says, you've gone all white.  I said, fuck me, I've been in prison half my life, what d'ya expect. But he was dead on, 'cause I could feel the blood drain right out of me head. And I knew ... (beat) Something had happened to Jen. They stand here a while.  Listening to the BREAKERS hit the shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT.  NIGHT. They come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make yourself at home.  Steal something. That gets her a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing I can't afford to lose. She goes to make coffee.  Wilson looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you even know who Terry Valentine is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I gathered something from the article what Eddie sent me.  Some sort of pop music producer, wasn't it. Maybe a smile from Elaine at the quaintness of "pop" music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rock n' roll, is what we called it.  He's sort of a forgotten figure now, but back when the West Coast was the grooviest place on earth, Terry Valentine was where all the happenings happened.  More of a kind of promoter, I guess, whatever that means.  Just took that whole Southern California Sixties Zeitgeist and ran with it.  Packaged and sold it.  Made out like a bandit. FLASH CUTS: VALENTINE. At home. Watching as Adhara undresses, either deliberately for him, or just casually. She smiles as she notices he's looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he done lately. That line pregnant with meaning.  Elaine looks at him. Avoids answering the question actually implied there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (brings a tray over) Lives high off the hog and waits for the next big thing.  Like me -- but on a grander scale of failure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, you shouldn't run yourself down.  My employer, Mr. Lindgren -- ELAINE -- Your employer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lindgren.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Mr. Lindgren?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My employer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What line is he in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Proprietor of a London firm.  Of longstanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Based in London, but with international concerns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Various enterprises, style of thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you said you never did an honest day's work in your life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, not to say Mr. Lindgren is dishonest, exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (she gets the picture) Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyhow, he's always saying to me, Dave, never run yourself down, son -- 'cause there'll always be plenty of people willing to do it for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In what capacity are you employed by this Mr. Lindgren?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This and that.  Y'know.  Ways and means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When he wants someone run down, you're willing to do it for him. They sort of come together -- in mutual understanding -- and sit down.  Coffee steaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's the deal.  You and Terry Valentine at twenty paces.  Is that what this is about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you ever known me not to be. Elaine looks away:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fuckin' guys and your dicks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you want me to do.  Stay at home, twiddlin' me thumbs.  Doing sweet F.A. [Fuck All].
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't believe it was a car accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry's never going to give you satisfaction.  Not the type.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depends, don' it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On what.  What makes you so certain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll bloody well ask him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's the phone.  You want his number. WILSON That look again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got his number. ELAINE Past caring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to help you. She goes into a bathroom.  Shutting the door behind her. WILSON Sips coffee.  Bites into a cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. HILLSIDE.  UNDERBRUSH.  LATE AFTERNOON. Thickets part and we SEE Wilson scrambling up a rather steep hill.  Coming to a ridge where he settles down to look at something O.S.  His expression changes by degrees from curiosity to dawning realization to a kind of frustrated disappointment. INT. WILSON'S CAR (ON THE ROAD BELOW).  LATE AFTERNOON. Ed sits in here, RADIO on.  Wilson appears out of the brush, gets in.  Ed turns the radio down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (mindful of the odd car driving past) Told you you wouldn't be able to see through that gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gate's open.  I had a butcher's at the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (alarmed) Who'd you butcher at the house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Butcher's hook.  Look. (doesn't anyone speak English in this fucking country?) I don't much reckon those minders of his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's brought in the heavy mob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extra muscle.  Bodyguards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look a right load of wallies. Patrolling back and forth outside the gate, all ponced up like the fuckin' Household Cavalry. (ducks suddenly) Watch it. As one of the "bodyguards" runs by, only fleetingly glimpsed by us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was one of them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sits up again) See what I mean?  Wearing bloomin' uniforms n' all. Off Ed's perplexed look ... EXT. HILLSIDE UNDERBRUSH.  LATE AFTERNOON. Wilson settles into position again, this time with Ed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that. Ed just laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's so fucking funny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those aren't guards.  They're valets. POV Now we SEE what Wilson had mistaken for Valentine's private army.  Half a dozen VALETS outside Valentine's hilltop home. Dressed in matching attire, a couple of them wielding walkie- talkies. RESUME WILSON AND ED Ed's still laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valets.  What d'ya mean valets.  What is he, then, the Earl of fucking Doncaster?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  LATE AFTERNOON. Wilson's car pulls up.  He and Ed get out.  Wilson engages in a mini tug-of-war with a Valet over his car key, it so rubs him the wrong way having to give it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep it handy, mate, all right?  We're not stopping long. He gestures, apparently getting the message across that he wants the car kept close by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheers. Exchanges the key for a card -- which he turns over in his hand and studies curiously as they head inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valets, eh?  Aren't we all la-de-da.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nervous being here) I thought you just wanted to check out the house, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's what we're doin', n' it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one else is even here yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First in, first out, that's me. Looking over to note the multi-car GARAGE off the main house. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Wilson and Ed are among the first to arrive.  A smattering of other GUESTS.  Elaborate catered cuisine.  They mosey over to the wet bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen.  What can I get you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suggesting Ed take first crack) Dubonnet with a twist?  Baby sham? Tomato juice and Tabasco sauce? By now his whole dynamic with Ed is a verbal tease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Bartender) Got a Coke? INT. VALENTINE'S BEDROOM.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is checking himself in a full-length mirror.  TV on in background, sound low (ENTERTAINMENT WEEK!).  Not quite satisfied, Valentine crosses to the bathroom. BATHROOM Valentine takes one more closer look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have the same posters. Valentine turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm? ADHARA Is lounging in the large tub.  Staring dreamily at a couple of framed posters on the walls:  more 60's psychedelia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you have down at your office. Valentine sits on the edge of the tub.  With a nostalgic air as he looks at her:  the embodiment of youth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Different ones. He strokes her wet skin.  They kiss lightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like the colors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It must've been a time.  A golden moment. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you ever dreamed of a place ... you don't really recall ever having been to ... a place that probably doesn't even exist except in your imagination ... somewhere far away, half-remembered when you wake up ... but when you were there you spoke the language, you knew your way around ... (significant pause) That was the 60's. With that exit line (practiced?), he starts to go. Then pauses, turns again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it wasn't.  Wasn't either. Comes back to her.  Faraway look in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was '66 ... early '67. (comes back to now) That was all. He goes. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Wilson wanders around, exploring the house.  Comes to a wall of photographes.  Casually scanning them as he passes slowly by, he's caught up short by one. POV A framed photo of JENNY, his daughter. WILSON A series of emotions play over his face.  He turns -- SEES Valentine coming down the stairs.  Valentine joins the party without noticing him. BY THE BUFFET TABLE Ed peruses the available food.  Valentine comes over to check it out.  Glances at Ed without recognizing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. And goes away.  Leaving Ed more nervous than ever. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Wilson has come up here.  Peeks into one room.  Moves along to another:  the master bedroom.  Opens the door gently. INT. MASTER BATHROOM. Adhara is still enjoying her bath. INT. MASTER BEDROOM. Wilson enters.  Careful.  Aware that someone's in the adjoining bathroom.  The soft RIPPLE of WATER from in there.  Perhaps he even glimpses her through the door as he boldly looks around. He notices a video camera on a tripod, a cord running to the television.  Suddenly we hear the CHIRP of a cellular phone. BATHROOM Adhara reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit. She gets out of the tub and goes for the nearest towel. Quickly wrapping herself, she exits. BEDROOM Adhara enters and goes for her purse.  She pulls the RINGING phone out and answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?  Hey!  Great.  You got my message? Yeah.  No, Crestview Terrace, not Crestview Place.  Yeah, there's like three different ways up the hill; the quick way is to bear to the right.  Sure.  Okay. Okay.  'Bye! She hangs up and begins toweling her hair.  After a moment she stops.  Something isn't right.  She looks around the room, and her eyes stop on the TV.  Her brow furrows, trying to place the familiar image on the screen:  a girl towel- drying her hair by the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's me. She looks over to see the video camera, which has been turned on and pointed toward the bed.  She's not sure if it's funny or creepy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Valentine mingling, all smiles and movement. WILSON At the foot of the stairs.  Watches him, all stillness and intensity. VALENTINE Catches Wilson's eye for a nanosecond, does a subtle double take, then moves on. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Adhara, dressed, looking great, exits the bedroom and heads for the stairwell. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Adhara descends the stairs. WILSON Turning to SEE her as she comes down. ADHARA Makes her way across the room to Valentine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, I thought you weren't a buffet person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a gracious host. WILSON Watching them, when -- GUY Excuse me? Wilson looks at him.  Reluctantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you work with Ian?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ian?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could swear I met you with Ian at the
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valets .  They park cars.  He's having a
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: offices in London.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.  Wasn't me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unless I'm not who I think I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too bad.  Ian's got a good thing going over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turned that place completely around.  180 degrees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I like about Ian, he believes in a chain of command, but not a chain of respect, you understand what I'm saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.  Chain of respect.  That's good, that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I really admire the guy.  Well. Good to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Cheers, mate. The Guy leaves.  Wilson sees that Adhara is now on the other side of the room, separated from Valentine.  He heads for her. VALENTINE Still dealing with people desperate to be the focus of his attention.  He notices: WILSON AND ADHARA Talking in a corner.  She seems attentive. VALENTINE In a SERIES OF CUTS, still being the gracious host, still keeping his eyes on: WILSON AND ADHARA Who, in a SERIES OF CUTS, continue to talk.  Finally, they separate, Wilson heading outside onto a deck. VALENTINE Excuses himself from a group of sycophants and goes to her. ADHARA Valentine approaches and begins talking to her, low.  After a few moments of conversation, they both look toward: WILSON On the deck outside.  Joining Ed, who's taken refuge out here with a plate of food.  What Wilson can't belleve when he SEES it -- is that behind Valentine's house, which is on top of a high hill, is nothing but desolate scrub canyon.  On the other side of the railing around the deck, which is surely less than regulation height, is a sheer drop into an abyss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (jumps back with only slightly affected vertigo) Flipping heck. Ed, a little more accustomed to L.A. architecture, nods in agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you could afford a house like this you would buy a house like this. Wilson edges forward to the rail again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we standing on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faith. They stand there looking out.  Quite a view once you get used to it.  Breeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods to the hazy distance) You could see the sea from here if you could see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you? But now Ed gives Wilson a nudge -- SEEING that Valentine inside the house is making his way out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go nick one of those little cooker what's its warming up the sausages cocktail and meet me in the garage.  Look about for a toolbox while you're at it. Ed considers.  His is not to reason why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Ed moves off.  Valentine steps up, smile fully loaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.  Terry Valentine. He extends his hand.  Wilson shakes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have we met?  There's something I can't quite -- WILSON EMI in London.  I work with Ian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must know Ian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great bloke.  Really turned things around there.  180 degrees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose that's good, unless things were fine the way they were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I think a shake-up was in order. Definitely.  Otherwise, people get lazy, don't they?  Forgetful.  Start thinking they can get away with things.  Gotta shake 'em up now and again, make 'em pay attention. Wilson looks at him.  Valentine looks back.  Something about those eyes ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry, Terry ... The Excited Guy appears, tugging at Valentine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glad I got to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ter ... Ter ... you gotta ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.  You, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be seein' you. The Excited Guy ushers Valentine away.  Wilson watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles Grodin is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. VALENTINE'S GARAGE.  AFTERNOON. Ed, waiting.  Wilson enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got it? Ed displays the Sterno.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Toolbox? Ed points to a table, where a toolbox sits.  Wilson crosses to it, begins going through the contents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put the Sterno on the ground, near the center of the garage. Ed does.  Wilson pulls a brace-and-bit from the toolbox and crosses to the rear of one of the cars.  Dropping to the ground, he bores a hole in the gas tank.  Ed raises his eyebrows and moves toward the door.  Wilson crosses to the other car and puts a hole in that gas tank as well.  Then he puts the brace-and-bit back in the toolbox and heads for the exit, Ed right behind him, giving a quick backward glance. THE GASOLINE Spills out, slowly but steadily, and slithers toward the garage door. EXT. BETWEEN VALENTINE'S HOUSE AND GARAGE.  AFTERNOON. Wilson and Ed walk briskly along the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gives Ed parking ticket) Bring the motor around.  Bang out in front, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You goin' back inside?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thing I need. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is talking to Gordon, his beefy bodyguard, and looking around.  He stops as he sees Wilson once again stepping onto the deck.  He points Wilson out to Gordon, who nods and heads for the deck. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Ed hands the ticket to a Valet.  He exchanges looks with a couple of the other Valets. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is talking to Adhara, who is introducing her Girlfriend.  As Valentine greets her, he glances outside where Gordon is approaching Wilson on the deck. EXT. DECK. Wilson SEES Gordon approaching.  Gets ready to greet him. Removes cigarette from mouth, drops it to floor of deck, presses it out under his shoe.  Limbers up his shoulders in a subtle way. Gordon coming towards him.  As if to challenge Wilson's legitimacy as an invited guest.  Closer.  About to speak. But Wilson doesn't even give him a chance to do that.  In quick succession:  Wilson HEAD BUTTS Gordon, splintering his nose; KNEES him in the groin; then, using the knee for leverage, grabs Gordon by the lapels -- and heaves him over the railing! It happened so fast that if anyone else is nearby they probably didn't even notice -- or didn't readily grasp what they saw. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE. Valentine had turned his attention back to Adhara and her Girlfriend.  When he glances back to the deck he's a little concerned not to see Gordon anywhere out there anymore -- just Wilson coming back in. WILSON Adjusting his jacket, walking back through the house. direction.raw_text: Do us a favor.  Can't even go have a slash without 'em saying, what're you going in there for? EXT. ELAINE'S BUILDING.  DAY. Elaine and Wilson enter.  Stacy not far behind.  Catches outside gate before it slams shut.

direction.raw_text: . INT. ELAINE'S BUILDING.  DAY. Wilson and Elaine turn the corner into the corridor approaching her apartment door.  Pause to kiss.  Walk closer. And Stacy appears at the other end of the hall.  Both arms stretched out with the .38 at the end of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, kids. Starts to squeeze off a shot.  As Wilson pushes Elaine to the floor.  As another SHOT rings out from further along the hall behind Stacy.  Catching him across the cheek.  Only skimming him.  But knocking him down.  Bullet chipping the wall. UNCLE JOHN Across from Stacy.  Freezes, his own gun in hand. AT THE STAIRS Three BLACK GUYS.  Including Thompson.  They approach.  Guns pointed at Stacy and Uncle John. WILSON Hand on his .45 now.  But a fourth Black Guy coming up behind him.  Wilson lowers the .45. ELAINE Flattened herself back against a wall.  Petrified. STACY Sits on the floor.  Holds his hurt face.  Thompson walks over and picks up Stacy's gun.  One of the other blacks relieves a reluctant Uncle John of his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stops at Wilson) Come with us. If there's any doubt whether Wilson will -- one of the blacks gently puts the muzzle of a gun to Elaine's head.  Cocks the hammer. They all go off down the stairwell.  Except Stacy and Uncle John. Hit men wondering what hit them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. ROOM.  DAY. Like Wilson's motel room, another version of a cell. A small window, high up.  Bricks and debris around the floor. And Wilson and Elaine.  Sitting, leaning against opposite stone walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me you wouldn't prefer a steady income. Wilson takes a cigarette pack from a pocket.  Lights himself one.  Then tosses the stuff over to Elaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a steady income -- I'm on the dole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (lights up) A leech on the welfare state in addition. You don't miss a trick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I fiddle it.  They got me down as an immigrant with five kids. Elaine sort of shares a laugh at that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah ... Jenny spoke fondly of her imaginary siblings. Though real ones might have been nice.  This an unspoken thought between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you remember the last time you saw her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last time might as well've been the first.  I remember all the times, don't I.  Watching her grow up -- (finding the word) in increments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She told me you were a ghost in her life. Daddy the friendly ghost.  Coming back to haunt her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, she twigged by the time she was eight or nine that daddy wasn't in the Royal Marines or doing scientific research in the jungles of Borneo or playing Iago in a worldwide tour of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still, you could never ... do what she wanted. Wilson shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She used to tell me she'd turn me in. (tries to laugh about it) Little kid.  Ten year old.  "If you're naughty, Dad, I'll tell on ya."  She didn't want me sent down again, see. When I was planning some job.  "I'll tell 'em, Dad, I promise I will.  Here, look, I'm calling the Old Bill right now" -- picking up the telephone.  I can see her, the phone in her hand.  Became a sort of joke between us.  Only it wasn't a joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She never would have turned you in, not in a million years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that.  But as time went on ... well, it wasn't a joke, was it?  She had a feeling about it -- about the last job
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: how long I'd get the hook for.  Said she wouldn't be there this time when I got out. DOOR opens.  Thompson.  Gun in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. HALLWAY.  DAY. Thompson leads Wilson past a row of windows.  Dockyards, harbor activity outside.  Toward a door with things stencilled on it.  One of them:  US DEPT. OF CUSTOMS. INT. OFFICE. A man named FEATHER.  Black.  Half sitting on the edge of a table.  Wilson is shown in. Wilson at the door.  Sizes Feather up at a glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is where I come in. He walks confidently in.  Outside, through the window, an image of a foreign sports car being hoisted in the air by a crane. There's a chair.  Wilson sits in it. Feather squints a little.  Seems ready to listen to whatever Wilson has to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it going, squire, all right?  Now listen -- when I was in the nick -- second time, it was -- no, third.  Third stretch, yeah.  There was this screw had it in for me.  That geezer was top of my list.  Two years after I was slung, I saw him.  He was sitting on a bench in Holland Park.  There was no one else about.  I coulda gone up behind him and snapped his fucking neck.  But I left it. Coulda nobbled him, but I didn't.  'Cos what I thought I wanted wasn't what I wanted.  What I thought I was thinking about was something else.  This berk on the bench wasn't worth my time.  See what I mean?  It didn't matter.  It meant sod all in the end. Feather has been listening to this, expressionless.  Now he raises a finger as if there's a point he wants clarified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's one thing I don't understand. (wants to make this clear) The thing I don't understand ... is every motherfucking thing you're saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, mush, you're the guv'nor here, I can see that, I'm on your manor now, right.  So there's no need to get out of your pram.  I'm Johnny-come-lately to all this.  Whatever the bollocks between you and this slag Valentine, it's got nothing to do with me.  I don't wanna know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you.  I believe this Valentine screwed me out of a fair sum of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can well believe it.  I'm sure he has done, son.  He's about as straight as a dog's hind leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I can't be sure.  I don't even know who he is.  He's too insulated.  Too many layers around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your guess is as good as mine, mate.  I'm here on another matter entirely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moves to window) Yeah, I guess you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good job your lot showed up when they did or it would've been me for the high jump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That dude who works for Valentine.  He's the one sent those guys after you.  You know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Shouldn't wonder.  Must've done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's your beef, pal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing financial.  Strictly personal. (moves to window) I can see how all this import-export malarkey might give rise to confusion where I'm concerned.  A foreigner, showing up unexpectedly, like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looks at him) It was you.  Downtown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (all innocent) Eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because that wasn't anything to do with me.  And suspicion has been cast in my direction. (pondering) Didn't make any sense.  Choosing those shitheads over me, cutting me out of the deal, then screwing them over too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I can reassure you on that point. Valentine was just as surprised by that turn of events as you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd already grabbed more than his allotted cut.  Didn't think he'd be so bold as to take all of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of the deal, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah, right.  The deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But if you're mad at him too and he's mad at you ... that must make us pals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As you prefer, squire.  As you prefer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (weary of his life) In which case I'll just do what I usually do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I doing? He's standing at the window, staring out.  As if Wilson isn't even in the room any more.  A ship being loaded out there. Inspectors with clipboards.  Trucks like the ones we saw at that warehouse downtown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking the other way. (turns to go) Gotcha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. INN.  DAY. Along the way up the coast. Through a window we SEE Valentine and Adhara enjoying a pleasant lunch. The bodyguards hang out by the cars outside with fast food bags and drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Rick) I mean, how much are you getting?  Just as a point of interest.  See, I didn't realize there was a sliding scale. AVERY At a payphone.  His idiots in the background.  Dials a number. INT. POOL HALL.  DAY. Stacy.  Nasty bruise on his cheek.  Takes a cue off the rack. Chalks up.

But doesn't get past Uncle John.  Who drops him with one punch.  Flooring him between two pool tables.  Stacy then goes over.  Supports himself with a hand on each table, swings his boot into the thug's face.

direction.raw_text: . EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  L.A.  DAY Someone we've never seen before and will never see again stands in Valentine's driveway.  His name is FIELDING. A car comes up.  Another guy, GRAMMS, sits in it.  He waits. Eventually Fielding walks over.

direction.raw_text: Deals?  My client is involved in any number of deals at any given moment. You'd have to be more specific.

direction.raw_text: You just cooking then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, no.  I started writing. Elaine and Wilson exchange glances. EXT. HIGHWAY.  DAY. Onwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BAR.  DAY. Stacy and Uncle John sit and drink.  Uncle John lamenting their monetary loss.  Stacy thinking to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We coulda used the other two-and-a-half grand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's more than a measly few grand in this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something's on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I happen to know more about Mr. Whatever- his-name-is than he thinks I know about him and his operation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like he'd never hire me for real.  Not week-to-week.  I don't have the credentials.  He thinks I'm just a sociopath, someone he can turn to when he needs "plausible denial."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we blew it, didn't we?  He ain't wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (savage mimicry) "He ain't wrong."  Listen, I know this asshole who did just go to work for him. Full-time.  And this dickhead's parents just told me he took a road trip up the coast. That's the type of individual gets hired, someone who'll shoot his mouth off to his family while on the job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know who that English guy is. Some kind of -- (finding the word)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: courier or something.  Maybe a seller. Maybe a buyer.  But Mr. Avery wanted him, those jigs wanted him -- and I betcha there's a briefcase somewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrugs) Drugs?  Cash?  Both if we're lucky.

direction.raw_text: How we gonna get that lucky?

direction.raw_text: While they're all fucking each other over ... couple of parties like us could move right in.

direction.raw_text: . EXT. HIGHWAY.  DAY. Wilson's car. Closer to Big Sur.  Scenery more magnificent. INT. WILSON'S CAR. Ed still driving.  Wilson next to him.  Opening a new cigarette pack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been wondering something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any friends, man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I suppose.  Call 'em that, yeah. Down the boozer Saturday night.  Meet some of the lads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little more pointed) Friends and colleagues .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't count on very many people, that's the trouble.  Number of times a decent job's been cocked up ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor baby. Little back-seat sarcasm there.  Wilson looks kind of bitter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Useless gits.  I was gonna do the Post Office once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What post office?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lot.  The whole British bloody Post Office.  I had a brilliant plan -- all worked out -- work of genius, it was. Could I get anybody interested?  No -- they're too busy pinching orange squash from the milkman.  Lazy sods.  Jumble sale on in Watford, they'll be up at the crack of dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're just on a higher plane, Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too bleeding true, 'n' it. Flicks some cigarette pack paper out the window. EXT. HIGHWAY. The car speeds along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. HOUSE.  BIG SUR.  DAY. An impressive clifftop dwelling.  Isolated on a winding road. On a beautiful promontory overlooking the sea.  Valentine RINGS the DOORBELL (actually CHIME).  It's opened by his ex- wife.  SUSAN.  Very well-maintained.  50-something. Surprised to see him.  But not overjoyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exercising my visitation rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since when?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss my kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're at college.  Or doesn't your accountant even tell you where the money goes anymore. Valentine goes inside. INT. HOUSE. He looks around.  She doesn't shut the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've made it ... brighter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want you here, Terry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you do. He turns to look at her.  Smiles.  Somehow it doesn't work on her.  One of the reasons she divorced him.  Just one.  She sighs.  Resigned to his presence.  Starts to close the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't shut the door -- I have people with me. Now she gets it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of trouble are you in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No trouble. Susan SEES Adhara get out of the sporty car parked in the drive and stand against it in a posture of younger chick defiance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surely you can think of somewhere else to take one of your chippies for a quick getaway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan. He actually puts his hands on her arms.  To hold her firm while he locks onto her eyes.  And doesn't smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just need ... somewhere remote.  Away from L.A.  For a couple of days. (now the kicker) I pay for this house too. Susan reads him.  He's not claiming ownership rights.  He's telling her this house, because of the connection to him, is a target of some kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you done? The Land Cruiser pulls up outside.  Avery emerges, comes over, comes in.  Susan notes the bodyguards out there as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Valentine) We weren't followed. (to Susan) Susan. Valentine lets Susan go.  Knowing she's now speechless at what's turned into, as far as she's concerned, a home invasion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moving, looking around) Where's ... what's-his-name -- Fred -- SUSAN -- You know his name is Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I don't live with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to him.  Go to his studio, or writers workshop or artists colony, Esselin retreat, nudist camp -- SUSAN Are you finished?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a couple of days this whole thing -- SUSAN Who's looking for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go now. Encouraging, if not in fact ushering, her towards a bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been five minutes and I'm packing to leave again.  I can't believe this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, your life is Shit, and I'm to blame.  It's that simple. That does it.  Susan turns on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is that simple.  I blame you for everything .  Losing inhibitions and chicks without bras didn't have to lead to hardcore porno in every American household:  that was you .  The first on your block to turn on a camera in a hot tub and peddle it to your friends.  A little recreational pot didn't inevitably have to lead to the eventual devastation of the inner cities: you made that happen, the first time you bought a bigger stash than you yourself meant to smoke.  It happened when you made your first buck hyping some so-called "event" that was over before it began or marketed some "product" whose only value was its instant disposability.  You were the first person to see there was a lot of money to be made selling Navajo rugs -- you've even stolen from the fucking Indians!  You looked at Charlie Manson when all he had to show for himself was a guitar instead of a knife and saw another merry prankster, the freedom of the frontier.  Your pal here -- (Avery)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He saw gated communities.  Rich people coming to him with their money, terrified of what people like you had left of this society.  Why invest in a marriage and children when you had him ? He's your oracle.  But you couldn't even trust in friendship, could you?  Still he's the dog you call for its dinner.  Because everything that might once have been fun or nice or sweet you had to turn mean and cold and sour.  That was your "genius," Terry.  Haven't you read your own press?
direction.name: direction

At her as if to say ... maybe farewell. EXT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  NIGHT. Tableau.  Evening has descended.  Surfaces glisten from a light drizzling rain. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE, BEDROOM.  NIGHT. Adhara, dressing.  Behind her, outside, way out of focus, a figure slithers by. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE, LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Valentine and Avery sit watching TV (CELEBRITY REPORT!).  Tom is behind them in the kitchen, flipping through Marie Claire magazine. VALENTINE Turns to look through the sliding glass doors. HIS POV Beyond the deck stands Larry, his back to us, facing the ocean. EXT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  BACK YARD.  NIGHT. Looking toward the house, Larry in the foreground, facing us. He takes a bite from a cinnamon granola bar, then looks at it unhappily as he chews.

REVERSE ANGLE Wilson and Ed watching him.  Wilson nods his head to the left, and Ed moves in that direction.  Wilson moves quietly off to the right. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Valentine and Avery, still watching TV.
